sub_title: Master civil engineering student interested in urban planning and stormwater management systems design.
summary: I am a first-generation graduate student in the Netherlands focused on learning about innovative stormwater management-based urban design, transportation planning, urban hydrology, and street and highway design.

projects.title: Amsterdam Data Analysis Project
projects.description: Utilize R packages including ggplot2, tidyr, rio, and dplyr to conduct an exploratory data analysis on CSV data scraped from Gemeente of Amsterdam databases to realize relationships between commerce activity and parking availability on a district level. Produce statistical data visualizations in an RMarkdown report with three colleagues, including contingency and summary statistic tables, and point, box, violin, hexbin, bar, line, and density plots facet-wrapped by district to guide Amsterdam policymakers’ understanding of local commerce activity on car parking. Optimize a complex regression model by utilizing R package car to run ANOVA analyses to iteratively identify the most influential predictors to the model using criteria Sum of Squares and P-score. Check goodness-of-fit by visualizing the distribution of model residuals.

contributors.headline: Master civil engineering student interested in urban planning and stormwater management systems design.
MSc student Metropolitan Analysis, Design and Engineering (Joint Degree TUD & WUR) at AMS Institute | Looking for a Graduation Internship from February 2024

projects.title: Climate and Catchment Hydrology Research Paper
projects.description: Analyze hydrological systems of catchments in various climatological and hydrogeological settings. Transfer a tool developed for natural catchments, which simulates rainfall as a Poisson distributed event, to an urban catchment to evaluate precipitation-runoff relationships at various temporal and spatial scales. Use leakage and saturation excess runoff as criteria to select the best type of soil for a roadside swale in a humid and transitional climate.

contributors.headline: Master civil engineering student interested in urban planning and stormwater management systems design.

projects.title: Enschede Urban Wadi Swale Dimensioning Project
projects.description: Conceptualize a Stationsplein at Station Enschede centered around an urban wadi from a placemaking and hydrological lens to improve vehicular accessibility to the station, and optimize the flow of people and vehicles to the city center. Force historical rainfall data to dimension the wadi to combat stormwater runoff and reduce nearby sensible heat flux.

contributors.headline: Master civil engineering student interested in urban planning and stormwater management systems design.

projects.title: MIT Senseable Cities Lab Amsterdam Air Quality Workshop
projects.description: Scrape Twitter data utilizing R from the Twitter Developer API by air pollution-related keywords to model the movement of people through dense areas of Amsterdam and their exposure to pollutants including NO2, black carbon, and ultrafine particles. Model visual AI machine learning by performing image classification, image object detection, and image segmentation on Google Street View imagery in Amsterdam with R to identify boundaries and colors of the images and detect pictured objects. Pitch a startup business idea to visualize NO2, PM10, and hay fever-related Twitter hotspots in real-time on a phone application to mitigate sensitive persons’ exposure to hay fever. Use Google Street View imagery to classify aggravating hay fever factors.

contributors.headline: Master civil engineering student interested in urban planning and stormwater management systems design.

projects.title: Transect Walk
projects.description: Tasked with observing the built and natural environment of Amsterdam Noord, our group produced a short movie focused on the metropolitan challenges of limited public seating, poorly-maintained vegetation, errant bicycle parking, and excessive noise pollution in Amsterdam.

contributors.headline: Master civil engineering student interested in urban planning and stormwater management systems design.

projects.title: Design of the Extension of Constitution Boulevard West in Shelton, Connecticut
projects.description: Evaluation of existing topographical conditions and local ecology using publicly available data, hand calculations, ArcGIS Pro, and OpenRoads. Hand calculations established the pre-development water runoff, infiltration, and storage. These approximations informed results derived using HydroCAD. Through the combined visualization of a 3-D terrain model, existing wildlife habitats, land use, wetlands, and property boundaries, three roadway alignment and profile proposal alternatives were developed. Each alternative was evaluated to determine the most cost-effective road design that minimizes environmental impacts, rock cut and fill requirements, and allows for future economic development that will not negatively impact water quality for the local community and regional ecology.

contributors.headline: Master civil engineering student interested in urban planning and stormwater management systems design.

projects.title: Groundwater Pumping Test Analysis Project
projects.description: Design a water resources exploitation protocol by analyzing observation well pumping test data using the Theis, Cooper-Jacob, and Thiem techniques in AQTESOLV to make inferences about aquifer homogeneity and confined nature.

projects.title: Maximum Pumping Rate of an Aquifer Project
projects.description: Utilize MATLAB to determine the maximum pumping rate to exploit an aquifer while remaining under pressure for 12 hours of pumping. Consider transient parameters, and an expected range of reliability of the design.

projects.title: Major Case Study Podcast
projects.description: For this course project, our CE 4730 group recorded a podcast episode to synthesize our research about the approaches and policies that have enabled Copenhagen, Denmark to become a world leader in sustainable transportation and urban planning.

contributors.headline: Master civil engineering student interested in urban planning and stormwater management systems design.

projects.title: Bridge Analysis Project
projects.description: Tasked with analyzing and modeling the real Yankee Doodle Bridge in Norwalk, CT, our CE 3610 group examined two loading conditions: normal loading conditions consisting of dead loads and vehicular loads, and an extreme loading condition comprised of fully-loaded semi-trucks halted on the bridge. We calculated reactions at the supports and the deflection of the bridge beams, and these calculations were modeled with 3D CAD software and physically demonstrated by a physical model bridge, which I built. The physical model was so successful, that it held upwards of 730 pounds without failure, and we ran out of weight to test the bridge with!

contributors.headline: Master civil engineering student interested in urban planning and stormwater management systems design.
Project Engineer at Consigli Construction Co., Inc.

projects.title: Differential Displacement Geotechnical Course Project
projects.description: For my Soil Mechanics course, in three project phases, we collaborated in a group of two students to calculate the differential displacement of the Leaning Tower of Pisa given Proctor Test results, Sieve Analysis test results, soil profile information, and Consolidation Test results. We then had to perform extensive calculations by using Microsoft Excel and Google Sheets to calculate ultimate consolidation settlement across both sides of the tower. Interesting but hard project, for sure!

contributors.headline: Master civil engineering student interested in urban planning and stormwater management systems design.

projects.title: Microstation Intersection Design Project
projects.description: This project was completed for two different courses: ENGR 1166 and CE 2411. Both times we used different rules and considerations, but the idea was to design the safest possible intersection in MicroStation given a base map and certain environmental and safety regulations. In the Spring of 2020, this was an introduction to Microstation, and in CE 2411 in the Fall of 2020, this was the entire Project we did at the end of the semester using everything we had learned about Microstation throughout the course!

contributors.headline: Master civil engineering student interested in urban planning and stormwater management systems design.

projects.title: Statistical Analysis Minitab Course Project
projects.description: In Probability and Statistics, our three-phase course project was designed to use the ideas we learned in class to help us gain an understanding of the concepts! We were given a set of porosity and hydraulic conductivity data taken from a soil sample on a highway embankment, and we had to use Minitab to calculate basic statistics, run hypothesis tests on both variables, run simple linear regression models with transformed data, and test for appropriateness of the simple linear regression model! I learned a lot about Minitab throughout the project!

contributors.headline: Master civil engineering student interested in urban planning and stormwater management systems design.

projects.title: SUMO and NETGUI Software Traffic Simulation Project
projects.description: For my Transportation Engineering class, we had to use the OSMWebWizard tool in SUMO to configure a randomized traffic demand at an elementary school (using the Terrain view) and run a traffic simulation scenario in sumo-gui. We had to add traffic modes, change the traffic volumes, and create paths within OSMWebWizard. Originally, we were supposed to use PTV Vissim for this project, but this was not adopted into the course.

contributors.headline: Master civil engineering student interested in urban planning and stormwater management systems design.
Staff Engineer at Dewberry

projects.title: Bridge Design Project
projects.description: In ENGR 1166, one of our two course projects for CE majors was to design and build a model Warren truss bridge out of balsa wood in a group of four total classmates to hold a minimum of 2kg. In the end, our final design held 13kg; it was the best design in class! For extra credit, we also had to code a Metro M0 Express board in Python and use an ARDUINO Ultrasonic Distance Sensor to measure deflection at bridge mid-span and trigger green, yellow, or red LED lights based on range of acceptable deflection values to model safely crossing the bridge.

profile_positions.location: Advanced Cementitious Materials and Composites Laboratory
profile_positions.description: I shadowed Postdoctoral, PhD, and Master's students in the ACMC Lab to assist in Ultra-High Performance Fiber Reinforced Concrete (UHP-FRC) testing, recording measurements and performing calculations on UHP-FRC samples, and understanding the effects of pyrrhotite on concrete aggregates. I worked together in a team of UG RA’s to make X-Ray Fluorescence (XRF) pellets used to measure elemental composition, organized incoming concrete foundation, wall, and slab samples in a team, and attended weekly meetings.
profile_positions.title: Undergraduate Research Assistant

profile_positions.description: My internship with Amtrak's Project Delivery department was an exciting opportunity to gain knowledge in construction and project management supporting Amtrak’s Northeast Corridor team. I worked collaboratively with Amtrak staff in Engineering, specifically project delivery, and was charged with focused support to project reporting, field information gathering, administrative support, and engineering technical support. To understand the magnitude of Amtrak’s annual operating plan investments and to support capital maintenance needs, I gained additional railroad engineering knowledge about track operations and ROW support structures. I also acquired skills and knowledge in the PMP - defined project phases: initiating, planning, execution, monitoring and controlling, and close out procedures; and coordinated in-house construction efforts within Amtrak-owned and/or maintained right-of-way, including track, bridges, buildings, signals and communications facilities, and electric traction facilities.
profile_positions.title: Engineering Project Delivery Intern

profile_positions.description: After COVID-19 hit, I had the opportunity to work at Baratza as an extra support agent, and built my interpersonal verbal communication skills by operating customer support phone lines to converse with customers and identify issues with their coffee grinders. I was able to successfully connect with both customers and senior support staff to ensure fast responses and respectful phone interactions. I also processed drop ship orders, as well.
profile_positions.title: Triage Support Agent

company.name: Eugene Sherman Real Estate Design & Development

This internship was an excellent exposure to construction project management, giving me insight into the development of a project.
profile_positions.title: Construction Operations Intern

profile_positions.description: During high school, I worked at Baratza to troubleshoot coffee grinders, assemble kits to upgrade grinders, ship grinder parts, and log parts into Microsoft Excel.
profile_positions.title: Assistant Technician

volunteer_experiences.description: I am the Chair for the Career Committee of the MADE-IT Study Association, an organization that provides bidirectional pathways that allow companies to connect with our MADE students through events such as Lunch Lectures, Career Fairs, Hackathons, and more!

Run by the UConn School of Engineering's Engineering Diversity and Outreach Center, the annual Engineering Your Future (EYF) conference is an opportunity for middle-school boys in 6th through 8th grade to gain exposure to engineering. In 2021, the conference was held entirely virtually, and together with a classmate, both of us ran the "Code a Rocket Launch" activity in Zoom Breakout Rooms. The activity introduced students to basic concepts and logic of Computer Science by coordinating a rocket launch and avoid obstacles along the way. We introduced basic computing ideas such as binary numbers, if/then statements, and certain syntax associated with coding.

I coordinated with Nancy Larson, manager at Bellevue School District's Facilities Department, to gather my peers to assist in weeding the entire infield of Ringdall Middle School's baseball field, and lay a new layer of dirt on top of the old layer. I was the manager for a 10-man daily crew for 2 months.

As an experienced baseball player who has been playing for 16 years, I volunteered at winter baseball clinics hosted by my local little leagues, Stafford Little League in Connecticut and Thunderbird Little League in Seattle!
Over two seasons of UW football, I volunteered to encourage people to recycle and how to properly dispose of their garbage!
Volunteering at Connecticut Food Bank to help sort incoming and outgoing food donations, firsthand witnessing the effects of our efforts in terms of poverty alleviation.
As an avid runner, over the course of a year, helped to set up courses at various locations to ensure smooth operations of various 5K's!
